channel.title: NPR Topics: National
channel.description: NPR coverage of national news, U.S. politics, elections, business, arts, culture, health and science, and technology. Subscribe to the NPR Nation RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: No, that wasn't Liam Conejo Ramos in Bad Bunny's Super Bowl halftime show
item.description: A publicist for Bad Bunny confirmed to NPR that the little boy in a blue bunny hat detained by ICE in Minneapolis last month did not participate in the Super Bowl halftime show.
item.content:encoded:
A publicist for Bad Bunny confirmed to NPR that the little boy in a blue bunny hat detained by ICE in Minneapolis last month did not participate in the Super Bowl halftime show.

(Image credit: Julio Cortez)
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: Seahawks ride their 'Dark Side' defense to a Super Bowl title, pounding the Patriots 29-13
item.description: The Seattle Seahawks have won the franchise's second Super Bowl, and defense was the driving force behind this championship.
item.content:encoded:
The Seattle Seahawks have won the franchise's second Super Bowl, and defense was the driving force behind this championship.

(Image credit: Sue Ogrocki)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Here's what happened at Kid Rock's alternative halftime show
item.description: Kid Rock headlined conservative group Turning Point USA's alternative halftime event.
item.content:encoded:
Kid Rock headlined conservative group Turning Point USA's alternative halftime event.

(Image credit: Alex Brandon)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: March for Life attendees may have been exposed to measles, DC Health warns
item.description: D.C. health officials are contacting people possibly exposed to measles at the March for Life in January, as confirmed cases rise nationwide.
item.content:encoded:
D.C. health officials are contacting people possibly exposed to measles at the March for Life in January, as confirmed cases rise nationwide.

(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)
item.dc:creator: Kristin Wright

item.title: Do you have some bad habits? Good news - you can make new ones. Here's how
item.description: Research shows it helps to start small if you want new habits to stick. NPR's Life Kit has more.
item.content:encoded: Research shows it helps to start small if you want new habits to stick. NPR's Life Kit has more.
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: How one New Hampshire town made sure its water was 'Safe to Drink'
item.description: NPR's Emily Kwong talks with Mara Hoplamazian about the new podcast, "Safe to Drink," about Merrimack, New Hampshire's fight for clean drinking water.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Emily Kwong talks with Mara Hoplamazian about the new podcast, "Safe to Drink," about Merrimack, New Hampshire's fight for clean drinking water.
item.dc:creator: Mallory Yu

item.title: Many American cities are digging themselves out of the snow. Where does it all go?
item.description: Many cities have been digging themselves out of the snow. But where does all of it go?
item.content:encoded: Many cities have been digging themselves out of the snow. But where does all of it go?
item.dc:creator: Ayesha Rascoe

item.title: Historian and law professor discusses the state of federalism in the U.S. under Trump
item.description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Alison LaCroix, a professor and historian at the University of Chicago Law School, about the state of federalism in the U.S. under President Trump.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Alison LaCroix, a professor and historian at the University of Chicago Law School, about the state of federalism in the U.S. under President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ayesha Rascoe

item.title: Developers are converting empty office buildings to keep up with demand for housing
item.description: Many U.S. cities have too many office buildings and not enough homes. Developers are now converting some old offices into apartments and condos, but it's going slowly.
item.content:encoded: Many U.S. cities have too many office buildings and not enough homes. Developers are now converting some old offices into apartments and condos, but it's going slowly.
item.dc:creator: Eleana Tworek

item.title: The model railroad world feels a pinch from global trade uncertainty
item.description: Model railroaders convene each year to celebrate their hobby. But this year they're wondering about the impact of tariffs on the foreign companies that make a lot of the products they collect.
item.content:encoded: Model railroaders convene each year to celebrate their hobby. But this year they're wondering about the impact of tariffs on the foreign companies that make a lot of the products they collect.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Lunden
